isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - Meritor Transfer Cases MTC-4208, -4210, and -4213 - Prepare Parts for Assembly - Inspect Parts

svcprocinfo.para: It is very important to inspect all parts carefully and completely before the transfer case is assembled. Check all parts for wear and stress. Replace all damaged parts.

step1.para: Inspect tapered roller bearings. Inspect the cup, cone, rollers and cage of all tapered roller bearings in the assembly. If any of the following conditions exist, the bearing MUST be replaced.

figure.caption: Figure 31. Inspect Cup, Cone, Rollers and Cage

step2.para: The center of large diameter end of rollers is worn level with or below the outer surface.
The radius at the large diameter end of rollers is worn to a sharp edge (Figure 31).
A visible roller groove is worn in the inner race surfaces of the cup or cone. The groove can be seen at the small or large diameter end of both parts.
Deep cracks or breaks in the cup, cone inner race or roller surfaces (Figure 32).
Bright wear marks appear on the outer surface of the roller cage (Figure 33).
Damage on rollers and on surfaces of the cup and cone inner race that touch the rollers (Figure 34).
Damage on the cup and cone inner race surfaces that touch the rollers (Figure 35).

step1.para: Inspect the gears for wear or damage. Replace worn or damaged gears.
Inspect the housing:

step2.para: Remove all dirt from the housing and oil lubrication passages, troughs, slots and holes.
Inspect machined surfaces for cracks and damage. Repair or replace damaged parts.

step1.para: Inspect all shafts, flanges and yokes for wear, stress and cracks at the splines, shaft and yoke ears. Replace shafts, flanges and yokes that are worn or cracked.
Verify that any oil passages in the shafts are clean and free of debris.
Inspect the declutch and output shaft components, if applicable:

step2.para: Inspect the clutch collar internal splines, external declutch teeth and shift for grooves. Replace worn, cracked or damaged collars.
Inspect the collar pads of the shift fork for wear. If the pads are worn, replace the shift fork.
Inspect the declutch shaft and yoke for wear, stress and cracks at the splines, shaft and yoke ears. Replace worn or cracked shafts and yokes.
Inspect the declutch or PTO push rod and piston for wear or damage. Replace worn or damaged parts.

step1.para: Inspect the splines on the pump inner rotor for cracks along the spline area. Also, check for excessive wear. Replace the pump if these conditions exist.
Remove and inspect the restrictor plug at the end of the input shaft.
Verify that the orifice is clear of debris.

svcsubproc.title: Helical Gears
svcsubproc.para: Inspect the helical gear teeth, splines and journals. If any of the following conditions exist, replace the gear:

item.para: A crack in the root of a tooth or along the tooth flank (Figure 36).
Severe scoring or fretting on the surface of a tooth. Gears with scoring and fretting on the teeth, but without cracks, may continue to operate satisfactorily with higher noise (Figure 37).
Cracks along the internal journal of the input gears (Figure 38).
Deep gouges or metal transfer along the input gear journals (Figure 39).
Chipped or severely worn shifting splines on the input gears.
Chipped or cracked splines on the output gears.

figure.caption: Figure 36. Crack in Root of Tooth
Figure 37. Scoring or Fretting on Surface of Tooth
Figure 38. Crack Along Input Gear Journal
Figure 39. Gouge Along Input Gear Journal

svcsubproc.title: Shafts
svcsubproc.para: Inspect the input and output shafts for damage to the gear journals, shifting splines, threads and gear retaining splines. If any of the following conditions exist, replace the shaft:

item.para: Deep gouges or metal transfer along the input shaft journals (Figure 40).
Chipped or worn shifting splines on the input shaft.
Chipped or cracked splines on the output shaft (Figure 41).
Cracks along the yoke splines, bearing journal abutments or cross-drilled holes. Magnaflux may be necessary to see small cracks.

figure.caption: Figure 40. Metal Transfer Along Input Shaft Journal

svcsubproc.title: PTO Components
svcsubproc.para: Inspect the PTO housing, shaft, taper bearings, shift collar, shift fork and sensors for damage. If any of the following conditions exist, replace the component:

item.para: Cracks in the housing.
Cracks along the shaft yoke spline or ball bearing abutment. Magnaflux may be necessary to see small cracks.
Chipped or cracked shifting splines on the shift collar or shaft.
The rollers of the taper bearings do not roll easily or lack lubrication. The raceway is cracked or dented.
Cracked or missing tangs on the shift fork arms.
The sensor ball sticks or does not return to its resting position. The sensors do not complete a circuit when tested with a volt-ohm meter (VOM).

svcsubproc.para: Inspect the shift collar, shift fork, shift shaft, retaining pins, shift cylinder, piston, O-ring and case halves for damage. If any of the following conditions exist, replace or repair the component:

item.para: Cracked or missing tangs on the shift fork arms.
Chipped or cracked shifting splines on the shift collar.
Cracks or deep gouges on the shift shaft.
The retaining pins in the shift shaft are not 0.100-inch (2.54 mm) above the shaft diameter. Remove and set to the correct position.
Gouges on the inside of the shift cylinder.
Torn or feathered areas on the O-ring.
Deep gouges in the shifting bores of the case halves.

svcsubproc.title: Oil and Lubrication System
svcsubproc.para: The lubrication system is extremely important to the performance of the transfer case. Inspect all parts closely for excessive wear or damage. Perform the following checks:

step1.para: Inspect the oil for metal shavings, dirt and consistency. Perform an analysis if the oil appears contaminated.

Check the magnets for metal shavings. A small amount of metal shavings is normal. However excessive build-up indicates gear and bearing damage. Thoroughly remove all metal shavings from the magnets. The magnets must be firmly fastened to the case.
Check the sump screen. Remove any material that may restrict oil flow through the mesh.
Inspect the seals closely. Look for nicks and tears on all sealing lips. Any damage is likely to result in a seal leak.
Check the pump for easy rotation. If the internal gear does not spin easily or jams when rotating the crescent plate, replace the pump.
Check the oil line for damage. Replace if it is dented or kinked.
Verify that the pump drive pins are 0.63-inch (1.6 mm) above the diameter of the shaft. Remove and set to the correct position if necessary.

svcsubproc.title: Transfer Case Halves
svcsubproc.para: Inspect the case halves for cracks and internal wear. If any of the following conditions exist, replace the damaged parts:

item.para: A crack in either case half.
Deep gouges in the shifting bores.

svcsubproc.title: Preparing Case and Cover and Seal Replacement

step1.para: Pry out all oil seals using a suitable pry bar.
As necessary, use a suitable puller to remove the bearing cups pressed into the transfer case halves.

Clean and inspect the transfer case and cover for cracks, worn threaded holes or other wear or damage. Clean the gasket surfaces of both transfer case halves using a suitable gasket scraper or wire wheel.
Press new bearing cups into the case halves as necessary. Refer to Idler Shaft Bearing End Play Adjustment in the ASSEMBLY Section for bearing setting procedures.
Inspect bearing end play to ensure that it's within specification. Adjust end play, if required. Refer to the ASSEMBLY Section.

Install new oil seals into the case halves. Use Meritor's seal driver, part number R4422402 for a 3.25-inch nominal diameter seal. The seal driver is included in Meritor's Kit 4454. To order this Kit, call ArvinMeritor's Commercial Vehicle Aftermarket at 888-725-9355 and specify Meritor Kit 4454.
